Article Title: CES 2026: Intel debuts Panther Lake AI chip for laptops
Article Text:
Intel Panther Lake chips availability





Intel has launched its new AI chips for laptops – Panther Lake at the ongoing Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas. Announcing the first line of Panther Lake chips known as Intel Core Ultra Series 3, Senior Vice President and General Manager, Client Computing Group, Intel said “With Series 3, we are laser-focused on improving power efficiency, adding more CPU performance, a bigger GPU in a class of its own, more AI compute and app compatibility you can count on with x86. ”Within the Intel Core Ultra Series 3 mobile lineup, a new class of Intel Core Ultra X9 and X7 processors come packed with the highest performing, integrated Intel Arc graphics. They are purpose-built for multitaskers that handle advanced workloads like gaming, creation and productivity on the go. The top SKUs feature up to 16 CPU cores, 12 Xe -cores and 50 NPU TOPS, delivering up to 60% better multithread performance, over 77% faster gaming performance and up to 27 hours of battery life3.The Series 3 family also includes Intel Core processors that are designed to power mainstream mobile systems. Leveraging the same foundational architecture of Intel Core Ultra Series 3, the Intel Core lineup enables more performant and efficient laptop designs at lower price points.For the first time, alongside their PC counterparts, Series 3 edge processors are certified for embedded and industrial use cases, including extended temperature ranges, deterministic performance, and 24x7 reliability.Intel Core Ultra Series 3 delivers competitive advantages in critical edge AI workloads with up to 1.9x higher large language model (LLM) performance, up to 2.3x better performance per watt per dollar on end-to-end video analytics, and up to 4.5x higher throughput on vision language action (VLA) models6. The integrated AI acceleration enables superior total cost of ownership (TCO) through a single system on chip (SoC) solution versus traditional multi-chip CPU and GPU architectures.Pre-orders for the first consumer laptops powered by Intel Core Ultra Series 3 processors will begin January 6, 2026. Systems will be available globally starting January 27, 2026, with additional designs coming throughout the first half of the year.Edge systems powered by Intel Core Ultra Series 3 will be available starting Q2 2026.
Article Summary: Intel has launched its new AI chips for laptops – Panther Lake at the ongoing Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas. The top SKUs feature up to 16 CPU cores, 12 Xe -cores and 50 NPU TOPS, delivering up to 60% better multithread performance and over 77% faster gaming performance.

Article Title: European head of one of the America's biggest consultancy company Mercer, managing $16.2 trillion assets, says: What keeps us awake at night is ...
Article Text:
Sharing the worry, Julius Bendikas European head of economics and dynamic asset allocation at

Mercer

, said, "What keeps us awake at night is that inflation risk has resurfaced." Mercer manages $683 billion of assets directly and advises institutions running a combined $16.2 trillion.

Deutsche Bank analysts' warning on AI spend





Global stock markets, riding high on AI euphoria at the start of 2026 may be disregarding one of the biggest threats: A surge in inflation driven partly by the tech investment boom; warn analysts. According to a report in Reuters, the US stock indexes, where seven biggest technology companies (called Magnificent Seven) made double-digit gains in 2025 to hit record highs as exuberance about AI. For those unaware, the Magnificent Seven stocks are a group of high-performing and influential companies in the US stock market: Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Tesla, Meta Platforms, Microsoft, and Nvidia. In the world of finance, the Magnificent Seven are a group of seven high-performing, influential stocks in the technology sector. The name comes from a 1960 John Sturges Western film, “The Magnificent Seven,” depicting a powerful group of seven gunmen.Analysts are reportedly worried that multi-trillion-dollar race by so-called hyperscalers like Microsoft, Meta and Alphabet to build new data centres is an inflationary force, because of the rate at which these projects are gobbling up energy and advanced chips. "The costs are going up not down in our forecast, because there's inflation in chip costs and inflation in power costs," Morgan Stanley strategist Andrew Sheets told Reuters.In fact, the stock markets have already shown some early signs of nerves about rising costs and potential AI over-spending.Deutsche Bank sees the scale of capital expenditure (capex) investment going into AI as gargantuan. The Bank expects AI data-centre capital expenditure to reach as much as $4 trillion by 2030 and the rapid rollout of these projects could cause supply bottlenecks in chips and electricity that make investment costs spiral, the bank's analysts warned. According to Deutsche Bank, hyperscalers cumulative spend of $4 trillion on AI data centers through 2030 is more than the U.S. government’s moon-landing program in the 1960s: “10x [the] inflation-adjusted cost of Apollo programme with no guaranteed return."You need a pin that pricks the bubble and it will probably come through tighter money," said Trevor Greetham, head of multi-asset at Royal London Asset Management. He said that while he was holding on to big tech stocks for now he would not be surprised to see inflation booming worldwide by the end of 2026.
Article Summary: Deutsche Bank sees the scale of capital expenditure (capex) investment going into AI as gargantuan. The rapid rollout of these projects could cause supply bottlenecks in chips and electricity that make investment costs spiral. According to Deutsche Bank, hyperscalers cumulative spend of $4 trillion on AI data centers through 2030 is more than the U.S. government’s moon-landing program in the 1960s.

Article Title: Microsoft Edge adopts Copilot's design language in major UI overhaul
Article Text:
Microsoft is giving its Edge browser a significant visual overhaul, adopting the sleek design of its Copilot AI. This refresh, currently in testing, brings rounded corners and new color schemes across the browser's interface. This move signals a broader push for a unified, AI-driven look across Microsoft's services, aiming to integrate experiences rather than launch entirely new ones.

A unified look across Microsoft's AI tools





Microsoft is rolling out a visual refresh for its Edge browser, borrowing heavily from the design language of its Copilot AI assistant. The changes are currently being tested in early Canary and Dev channel builds, marking what could be the beginning of a broader design shift across Microsoft's product lineup.The redesign touches nearly every part of the browser interface. The new tab page, settings menu, context menus, and dropdown elements all now feature the rounded corners, color schemes, and typography that debuted with the Copilot app. According to Windows Central, these changes appear regardless of whether users have Copilot Mode enabled, though the new tab page adapts based on the setting.This move represents a departure from Microsoft's established Fluent Design system, which currently powers Windows 11, Xbox, and Office. The Copilot design language originally emerged after most of the Inflection AI team joined Microsoft in 2024, bearing striking similarities to the Pi AI assistant Inflection had developed.Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman confirmed last year that the company plans to evolve Edge rather than create an entirely new AI-focused browser. "There isn't going to be a new browser; this is just going to be one experience," Suleyman told The Verge's Tom Warren.The Edge browser is not the only interface being reworked. In addition, Microsoft is also exploring the use of its copilot design language Copilot Discover, which is an AI-driven version of the MSN.com site. Although the new look has not been implemented in Windows or Xbox, the overall trend here is towards a unified look for its services, which is AI-driven.The new interface is currently in the preview stage, and it will probably be several weeks before it makes it to the stable version of the Edge browser.
Article Summary: Microsoft is rolling out a visual refresh for its Edge browser, borrowing heavily from the design language of its Copilot AI assistant. This move signals a broader push for a unified, AI-driven look across Microsoft's services. The new interface is currently in the preview stage, and it will probably be several weeks before it makes it to the stable version.

Article Title: Zo​​mato parent Eternal’s CEO Deepinder Goyal asked Blinkit CEO Albinder Dhindsa to step down twice after acquisition, here’s why
Article Text:
Left: Eternal CEO Deepinder Goyal | Right: Blinkit CEO Albinder Dhindsha

"Right after we acquired Blinkit, I asked him (Albinder) to leave. I told him, 'You will not be able to cut it.' He said okay. This happened twice during that timeframe, and we started the transition,"

"All of us have this armour. And when patient coaching runs out, I penetrate this armour. Me being angry is also because I care,"

What is Eternal CEO Deepinder Goyal said about ‘rock bottom phase’



"rock bottom"

"I call this rock bottom, where I hurt people, their self-confidence completely goes for a toss. I do this with people who I think have insane potential, but something in their head is coming in their way,

"

"Over time, the success rate of this is four out of five, where they come out of it,”





Deepinder Goyal, founder and CEO of Zomato 's parent company Eternal, has revealed that he asked Albinder Dhindsa to step down from his role twice shortly after the food delivery service acquired Blinkit. Goyal explained that this move was part of his tough leadership reset method. Speaking on a video podcast with Raj Shamani, Goyal noted that these conversations took place soon after the acquisition of the quick commerce startup, when Dhindsa was struggling to adapt to the changes required after the integration.Goyal said on the podcast.These remarks offer a rare public look at how Goyal handles senior leadership changes at Eternal, which owns both Zomato and Blinkit, especially when founders or top executives need to adapt to a new company structure after an acquisition. Goyal explained his leadership style involves extended periods of coaching, but if no progress is made, he confronts the person directly.he noted.The situation reveals the challenges that can arise when successful startup founders join larger organisations through acquisitions and must adjust their working style to fit the new company's expectations.Describing what he calls aphase, Goyal said he sometimes purposely breaks down a leader's confidence to make them start fresh.he explained.According to Goyal, this method has worked most of the time.he added.However, Goyal did not confirm whether Dhindsa's job or duties officially changed during this time. Still, his comments show how intense the process was of bringing Blinkit into Eternal, especially as the company was growing both Blinkit and Zomato while facing more competition in quick commerce.Zomato bought Blinkit, which was previously known as Grofers, in 2022 for Rs 4,447 crore, or about $568 million at the time, in an all-stock deal. This marked Zomato's official entry into India's rapidly growing quick commerce business. Since buying the company, Blinkit has become a key growth area for Eternal, opening many new stores and handling more and more orders.
Article Summary: Deepinder Goyal, founder and CEO of Zomato's parent company Eternal, has revealed that he asked Albinder Dhindsa to step down from his role twice shortly after the acquisition of Blinkit. Goyal explained that this move was part of his tough leadership reset method.

Article Title: When Mark Zuckerberg shared his basic hiring rule at Meta to tell college students: The most important decision you make in college is ...
Article Text:
FILE - Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg. (AP Photo/Nic Coury, File)

EXPOSED: Mark Zuckerberg Embarrassed on Hot Mic Admitting Total Confusion During Trump Dinner





Ever since Mark Zuckerberg announced the creation of Meta Superintelligence Labs in first half of 2025, Meta CEO has been on an AI hiring blitz. A Twitter user who goes by the moniker @HinataMotivates, said to be a tech-motivation account, shared a podcast clip (going back to 2022) where Zuckerberg talks about Meta hiring rule and his advice for college students. Mark Zuckerberg has a hiring rule that he says is cardinal for him while hiring anyone and the one that he says is also an important tip for any college student. In an episode of the “Lex Fridman Podcast,” hosted by MIT computer scientist Lex Fridman, Zuckerberg said that most people know Facebook ’s dorm-room origin story and that many have learned the wrong lesson from it. He said that his initial ability to launch Facebook wasn’t because he dropped out of college. According to Zuckerberg, it was due to the personal connections he made while he was still in school.Who you spend time with in college, Zuckerberg said, is “the most important decision” any student can make in college. He advised college students that choosing their social circle is the most pivotal decision, as people tend to emulate those around them. “You become the people you surround yourself with,” he said in the podcast.“I think probably people are too, in general, objective focused, and maybe not focused enough on the connections and the people who they’re basically building relationships [with]. ” Meta CEO Zuckerberg is said to have met his Facebook co-founders ⁠— Eduardo Saverin, Dustin Moskovitz, Chris Hughes and Andrew McCollum ⁠— while the five were students at Harvard University.While the group split up in a not-so-happy manner, Zuckerberg said on the podcast that he tries to prioritize relationships over objectives. This applies especially to hiring. Zuckerberg said that he extends the idea to his Meta hiring philosophy: He only employs candidates he did hypothetically work for, underscoring reciprocity and alignment in professional networks. When evaluating a job candidate, he imagines what it would be like to work for that person. “I will only hire someone to work for me if I can see myself working for them,” he said.Mark Zuckerberg said that the strategy creates a work environment that’s both more cohesive and more productive: If you work with people who share your values on a human level, you’ll be more likely to smoothly achieve your work goals together. It’s all about finding personal compatibility, he said, not unlike “choosing friends or a partner.”
Article Summary: Mark Zuckerberg has a hiring rule that he says is cardinal for him while hiring anyone. Zuckerberg said that his initial ability to launch Facebook wasn’t because he dropped out of college. According to Zuckerberg, it was due to personal connections he made while he was still in school.

This includes options such as thefeature, which identifies the month that has the lowest prices overall, while thetool provides day-by-day pricing for your chosen month.To use this feature, users have to enter their cities, click, and choose their preferred option. Once it's set up, users can review the grid showing the lowest recent fares and select dates that fit your budget. Both features work on Skyscanner’s desktop site and mobile app.The prices shown are estimates based on recent searches and can change quickly, so book soon when you find a good deal. Using these three tools together creates a complete money-saving system for finding affordable flights every time you travel.

Article Title: Why Google DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis thinks the AI startup valuation model is breaking
Article Text:
Big tech vs early-stage hype

'Trump Needs Indian Skilled Workers': Expert On Big Tech's AI Bet On India

Demis Hassabis makes his stand clear on AI scaling





Google DeepMind CEo Demis Hassabis has once again warned that the present wave of AI startup valuations is unsustainable. He also raised concerns that there are chances that the tech sector is heading towards a correction. Speaking on Google DeepMind: The Podcast, Hassabis said many early-stage companies are now raising tens of billions dollars before even launching product. He believes that this trend exposes cracks in the valuation model. “Some startups basically haven’t even got going yet,” Hassabis said. “It’s sort of interesting to see how can that be sustainable. My guess is probably not, at least not in general.” This increase in speculative funding has drawn comparisons to past bubbles, such as the dot-com boom and the crypto frenzy, where companies raised massive sums on hype rather than proven business models.Hassabis emphasised that these seed-stage valuations with investments by established companies like Google, which he said are backed by “a lot of real business.” While Big Tech’s AI bets are supported by revenue streams and infrastructure, many startups are relying solely on investor enthusiasm.He added that AI is “overhyped in the short term” but “underappreciated in the medium to long-term,” suggesting that while the technology’s potential is profound, the current funding frenzy may not reflect sustainable growth.Reflecting on DeepMind’s own early days, Hassabis noted how technological shifts often swing from skepticism to obsession, inflating valuations quickly. “It’s almost an overreaction to the underreaction,” he said, pointing out that investor sentiment can flip dramatically once a technology gains traction.Recently, Google DeepMind CEO also made his stand clear on the debate over how far AI scaling laws can take the industry.As reported by Business Insider, speaking at the Axios AI+ Summit in San Francisco, Hassabis said that scaling current systems must be pushed to the maximum, calling it a critical path towards artificial general intelligence (AGI). “The scaling of the current systems, we must push that to the maximum, because at the minimum, it will be a key component of the final AGI system. It could be the entirety of the AGI system,” Hassabis told the audience.AGI is still a theoretical form of AI which is capable of reasoning as well as humans. AGI is also the ultimate goal for leading AI companies that are driving billions in spending on infrastructure and talent. Scaling laws suggest that the more data and compute an AI model receives, the smarter it becomes.

He also raised concerns that there are chances that the tech sector is heading towards a correction. Article Title: Microsoft AI chief Mustafa Suleyman: Gemini 3 can do things that Copilot can’t, we are really trying to …

Mustafa Suleyman’s AI system warning

Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman recently said that Gemini 3 ‘can do things Copilot can’t do’. Article Title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang: I am not ambitious, I just want to…
Article Text:
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, despite leading a $4.4 trillion company, lives in constant fear of bankruptcy, working seven days a week. He revealed on The Joe Rogan Experience that his mantra is to run Nvidia as if it's "30 days from going out of business," a mindset forged by past near-death experiences.

Nvidia Makes History: First Company to Hit $4 Trillion Market Cap

Fear-driven leadership powers AI chip giant's success

Seven-day workweeks extend beyond executive suite





Despite leading the world's most valuable company with a $4.4 trillion market cap, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang operates in constant fear of failure. In a recent appearance on The Joe Rogan Experience podcast, the 62-year-old executive revealed he works seven days a week in a perpetual "state of anxiety" about the company going bankrupt."I'm not ambitious, I just want to stay alive," Huang told host Joe Rogan, explaining his 33-year mantra of running Nvidia as if it's "30 days from going out of business." The co-founder, who has led the chipmaker since 1993, said this feeling of vulnerability "doesn't leave you" despite the company's recent milestone of becoming the first public firm to reach a $5 trillion valuation in October.Huang's unconventional leadership approach stems from near-death experiences in the 1990s when Nvidia faced bankruptcy multiple times. He recalled flying to Japan to inform Sega that a contracted graphics chip was flawed and the deal should be canceled, while simultaneously admitting Nvidia needed the final $5 million payment to survive. Sega converted the funds into an investment, providing the lifeline that kept the company afloat."I have a greater drive from not wanting to fail than the drive of wanting to succeed," Huang explained. The CEO maintains his intense work schedule by waking at 4 a.m.daily to read emails for hours, processing several thousand messages each day. This routine continues through holidays including Thanksgiving and Christmas.Huang's relentless work ethic has influenced his family, with both adult children Madison and Spencer working at Nvidia seven days a week. The siblings, who are in their 30s, initially pursued different careers before joining the company as interns in 2020 and 2022.Nvidia reported record revenue of $57 billion for its third quarter, driven by surging demand for AI chips that power technology from Microsoft, OpenAI and Meta. However, Huang told Rogan that scale hasn't changed his mindset: "The sense of vulnerability, the sense of uncertainty, the sense of insecurity—it doesn't leave you."
Article Summary: Jensen Huang, CEO of $4.4 trillion AI chip giant Nvidia, lives in constant fear of bankruptcy. He revealed on The Joe Rogan Experience that his mantra is to run Nvidia as if it's "30 days from going out of business" Huang's unconventional leadership approach stems from near-death experiences in the 1990s when Nvidia faced bankruptcy multiple times.

Elon Musk has recently focused attention on the AI tool for the creation of images and videos by xAI’s Grok Imagine, with a thread about guidelines for the creation of aesthetically attractive and cinematic content. Elon Musk recently posted a thread that directed attention to a guiding article by AI enthusiast @karatademada with instructions and explanations that highlight the effectiveness of storytelling in improving the output of AI-generated media. Unlike common AI tools for the creation of images that depend on the description of an object, Grok AI is highly successful with descriptions that focus on emotion, ambience, lighting, and camera angles, according to the article posted by Elon Musk.Grok Imagine is an AI-powered creative tool designed to help users generate cinematic-quality images and videos from simple text prompts. By combining advanced image generation with dynamic visual styling, it allows creators to experiment with lighting, composition, and motion without technical expertise.Users of Grok Imagine are taught one of the most important lessons in moving away from simple, descriptive prompts.Instead of writing, "A woman walking on a street," for instance, they should be thinking about how to direct the scene: "Cinematic shot of a woman walking alone on a rainy Paris street at night, reflections of neon lights on wet pavement, filmed in 4K, directed by Christopher Nolan, atmospheric and moody. " By setting the mood and style, users really let the AI interpret the story behind an image rather than just objects in their own space.Grok Imagine does well with emotional context. Instead of "A happy girl under the sun," a more illustrative and emotionally evocative prompt would be: “Close-up of a carefree young woman laughing under golden sunlight, wind blowing through her hair, summer energy, cinematic lens flare, warm tone." By including how it should make the viewer feel in the image, the AI can create compositions that really carry emotional depth and engagement, making them appear much more lifelike and compelling.Camera perspective and cinematography terms are critical for creating dramatic scenes. New scenes can be improved or changed by stating the additional elements: Same picture, but include soft morning sunlight filtering through the window, a cup of cappuccino on the table, and the Paris skyline reflected in the glass. In much larger ways, complete scene transformation is also accomplished: Change the same scene into a cyber café scene in the future, a place of holographic menus and digital rain.The creation of better AI-generated images is an iterative process. Users can take the advice offered to improve their prompts through the use of language, style, and composition. An example would be to take a basic prompt, Portrait of a woman holding flowers," and improve it in the following manner: Cinematic portrait of a woman holding yellow tulips; soft focus; 85mm lens; soft morning light.

Article Title: When Amazon founder Jeff Bezos agreed that AI is in an 'industrial bubble' with investors who ...
Article Text:
‘AI is for real’



Investor concerns beyond Jeff Bezos







Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has once again cautioned that artificial intelligence is presently an ‘industrial bubble’, even he insisted that the technology itself is real and will ultimately deliver huge amounts of benefits to the society. Recently, speaking at the Italian Tech Week alongside Exor CEO John Elkann, Bezos said that the excitement around AI has led to unusual investor behaviour, with billions of dollars flowing into companies regardless strong fundamentals.Bezos explained that bubbles are characterised by inflated stock prices and a rush of funding into both good and bad ideas. This makes it difficult for the investor to distinguish.Bezos further outlined the hallmarks of bubbles. He said that the current AI climate as one where “every experiment or idea gets funded,” even if the fundamentals are weak. He pointed to unusual behavior such as small companies with only a handful of employees receiving billions of dollars in investment. This, he said, is a hallmark of industrial bubbles, where excitement drives capital into ventures indiscriminately.Despite this caution, Bezos feels that the technology itself is genuine and transformative. “AI is real, and it is going to change every industry,” he told the audience. He further compared the situation to the biotech bubble of the 1990s, which witnessed many companies fail but ultimately produced some life-saving drugs. Industrial bubbles, he argued, are not necessarily harmful; when the dust settles, society benefits from the inventions that survive.Bezos’ remarks echo a growing chorus of warnings from business leaders. Sam Altman, CEO of OpenAI, has previously said the AI market is in a bubble. At the same event in Turin, Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon cautioned that investor excitement often overlooks risks, predicting a “reset” or “drawdown” in valuations. Similarly, Karim Moussalem, chief investment officer at Selwood Asset Management, recently said the AI trade is beginning to resemble “one of the great speculative manias of market history. ”
Article Summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has once again cautioned that artificial intelligence is presently an ‘industrial bubble’ However, he insisted that the technology itself is real and will ultimately deliver huge amounts of benefits to the society. He said that the current AI climate as one where “every experiment or idea gets funded,” even if the fundamentals are weak.

What Microsoft engineer said about company’s method of handling angry customers



“A colleague of mine who used to work in product support told me that they had a procedure if a customer became irate and demanded to speak with Bill Gates. (This was, of course, back in the days when Bill Gates still ran the company.)

Their job was to tell the caller that Mr. Gates is currently unavailable, but if the customer leaves a message and their contact information, they will pass the information to Mr. Gates.

Maybe Bill got a copy or a summary of these messages, I don’t know.”

Article Title: Deepinder Goyal’s Temple wearable explained: How the device works, tracks blood flow, brain health, and ageing
Article Text:
Image source: YouTube

What Deepinder Goyal’s Temple device tracks and why brain blood flow matters



‘ Gravity Ageing Hypothesis ’ behind Deepinder Goyal’s Temple device



Deepinder Goyal’s personal role in testing the Temple







Zomato co-founder Deepinder Goyal on Raj Shamani’s Figuring Out podcast , which sparked interest not just for the content of Goyal's remarks but also for entirely different reasons. Online viewers were quick to notice a tiny metallic object that appeared to be affixed to Goyal’s Temple area, sparking rapid speculation throughout social networks. On one hand, comments tapered off into joking around about it possibly being some kind of chewing gum or perhaps a hidden charging connection for his phone or other devices. In truth, there is far more to this tiny device than one can imagine. Its name is Temple, and it is currently one such wearable that focuses on brain functions by monitoring the flow of blood in real time.Temple is a small wearable device resembling a clip that is clipped on the side of the Temple. This device continuously tracks blood circulation to the brain. The amount of blood supply that reaches the brain is understood to be a very relevant pointer to overall neurological function and the ageing processes of the brain. The continuous tracking offered by Temple will allow the wearer to see patterns of blood circulation when they are at work and active versus when they rest or are stressed.The brain requires a stabilised and constant blood supply to function.Any alteration in the blood flow to the brain has been associated with fatigue, lack of concentration, memory problems, and ageing-related cognitive impairments. Researchers have been studying the above in controlled environments with the aid of giant imaging machines, with continuous monitoring in real-life situations not easily possible. Temple seeks to fill the above gap by studying the brain in normal life situations rather than in a controlled environment.Temple's growth is based on what Goyal calls the ‘Gravity Ageing Hypothesis’. This proposal implies that the effect of the force of gravity pulling for many years may lead to a slight effect on the circulation of blood in the body, specifically the energy involved in pushing the blood towards the head for the brain to function properly. According to the hypothesis, the loss of effectiveness in the circulation of blood in the head may contribute to the ageing process. Although the hypothesis is popular, scepticism surrounds the idea because ageing is known to involve a complex interaction of genetic factors, environment, lifestyle, and diseases.Although it has generated a lot of buzz, Temple is still neither a Zomato product nor available for public use. The product has been privately developed by the parent organisation of Zomato, named Eternal, as a part of Goyal's private research initiative named Continue Research. The level of investment made into this project by Goyal has reportedly been to the tune of $25 million. There has been no declaration on the regulatory approval and pricing of the product, which again indicates it is purely a product in the experimental phase.Goyal has not used Temple as a completed product or as the result of a product launch. Rather, Goyal has been using the device on himself for the past year. This has been the result of his interest in health optimisation for quite some time, which has been previously stated by Goyal through public statements. This has included the use of tracking biological markers, fasting schedules, and other health-optimising modalities. Temple represents the natural continuation of these experiments, as Goyal could study the effects of these modalities on blood flow to the brain, with ongoing self-experimentation, data collection, transparency, and iterative refinement methods.
Article Summary: Temple is a small wearable device resembling a clip that is clipped on the side of the Temple. This device continuously tracks blood circulation to the brain. The amount of blood supply that reaches the brain is understood to be a very relevant pointer to overall neurological function and the ageing processes. The continuous tracking will allow the wearer to see patterns of blood circulation when they are at work and active versus when they rest.

American billionaire and Shark Tank investor Mark Cuban said that students these days use artificial intelligence (AI) excessively to ask the “right questions”. He has previously likened the current AI boom to past technological revolutions, particularly the rise of computers and the internet. “Spend as much time as possible familiarizing yourself with the latest AI tools and models, so you can impress future employers with your up-to-date prompt engineering and model customization skills,” an advice that he often gives to students, per a CNBC report.Speaking on an episode of the “TBPN” podcast in 2025, Mark Cuban said”“Every single company needs that. You and your household also have 24/7 access to a wide range of support and resources through Resources for Living.

Employee Guidance

The remote work grace period is subject to the same activity restrictions (listed below) as all current remote work guidance in India. In compliance with local laws, there are no exceptions to these restrictions. If you have questions, please work with your manager and HRBP to determine what activities you can engage in while abroad, based on these guidelines:

Do not code. This includes troubleshooting, testing, or documentation.

Do not work from or visit an Amazon building or site. All work must be remote from a residential address or other non-Amazon location.

Do not give the impression of authority to bind any Amazon entity or appoint an agent authorized to bind any Amazon entity to any contract or agreement.

Article Title: Goldman Sachs: Companies discussing AI in the context of employees or layoffs appear to ...
Article Text:
Biggest Tech Layoffs of 2025: Job Cuts at TCS, Intel, Microsoft, Google and more

'Clear evidence of layoffs directly motivated by AI remains limited'





Is AI leading to layoffs? This is the biggest question that analysts across spectrum have been trying to gauge. Goldman Sachs' recent economic analysis shows a bifurcated picture of artificial intelligence’s impact on the workforce. The findings are claimed to be based on an analysis of third quarter corporate earnings of nearly all the S&P 500 companies and results commentary by senior economist Ronnie Walker. While the analysis showed that a relationship between overall labor market outcomes and AI exposure at the economy-wide level has yet to be established, it also showed something else.“While we still do not find a relationship between labor market outcomes and AI exposure at the economy-wide level,” Walker wrote, “we find that companies that have discussed AI in the context of their workforce have cut their job openings more sharply this year.” Indeed, Walker wrote that most components of Goldman’s layoff tracker “increased notably” in recent months. He highlighted that the companies discussing AI in the context of their workforce or layoffs “indeed appear to be pulling back disproportionately on hiring. ” Walker said that management teams are increasingly viewing AI not just as a tool for efficiency but as a core component of their future human capital strategy, leading to preemptive cuts in new roles.Walker’s piece agrees with a previous analysis by his Goldman colleagues David Mericle and Pierfrancesco Mei, who argued in October that “jobless growth” may become a new normal feature of the post-pandemic economy. In his analysis, Walker found that the companies that most frequently discussed tariffs had “disproportionately cut job openings this year.” Some companies reportedly noted that they planned to reduce costs by “hiring less, reducing headcount, or pursuing productivity-enhancing initiatives (such as investing in AI solutions). ” Goldman Sach's research shows that AI has quickly become a central topic in conversations about headcount within the tech sector since November 2022.Walker found a “bifurcated” outlook, as his research agreed with many economists’ arguments that the U.S. has a “K-shaped economy,” where consumer spending is strong overall, but concerns about lower-income health abound. This underperformance is expected to continue for the low-end consumer into 2026, Walker wrote, reflecting tepid job growth and pressure from benefit cuts.In a related research in October 2025, Goldman Sach's economists Manuel Abecasis and Pierfrancesco Mei wrote, “So far, we do not find clear evidence that most of the increase in these measures is directly motivated by AI, even if we see large increases in tech layoffs across both the Challenger and WARN measures.” They added, “As our portfolio strategy team noted, only a small number of S&P 500 firms have explicitly referenced AI when discussing large-scale layoffs. Most companies instead point to the need to streamline and restructure operations, sometimes attributing these changes to new technologies that enable efficiency gains.”
Article Summary: Goldman Sachs' recent economic analysis shows a bifurcated picture of artificial intelligence’s impact on the workforce. The findings are claimed to be based on an analysis of third quarter corporate earnings of nearly all the S&P 500 companies.

Article Title: PWC US CEO Paul Griggs on what made the company change its stance on Crypto
Article Text:
"The

Genius Act

and the regulatory rulemaking around stablecoin I expect will create more conviction around leaning into that product and that asset class. The tokenisation of things will certainly continue to evolve as well. PwC has to be in that ecosystem,”

What PWC US CEO Paul Griggs said about the Genius Act

“We feel a responsibility to be hyper-engaged on both sides of the business. Whether we are doing work in the audit space or doing work in the consulting arena — we do all the above in crypto — we see more and more opportunities coming our way,”

“We are never going to lean into a business that we haven’t equipped ourselves to deliver. Over the last 10 to 12 months, as we’ve taken on more opportunities in that digital assets arena, we’ve bolstered our resource pool inside and outside,”





PWC has shifted its outlook on cryptocurrency . PWC US CEO Paul Griggs has confirmed that the company, which is also known as one of the Big Four accounting firms, has decided to “lean in” to cryptocurrency work following the Trump administration’s support for digital assets such as Bitcoin. This shift follows years of the company taking a cautious stance on cryptocurrency. In an interview with the Financial Times (FT), Griggs said that the reversal occurred as the US appointed pro-crypto regulators and Congress passed new laws, such as the “Genius Act”, to govern the industry.Griggs said to FT.These comments reflect how the Trump administration's cryptocurrency policy moves have convinced established businesses that they can enter the digital asset market that many had previously avoided. The change comes as regulatory clarity around digital assets has improved in the US, with new frameworks addressing stablecoins and other crypto products that previously existed in legal uncertainty.The Genius Act, signed into law by US President Donald Trump in July, was the first rule issued by the country for digital tokens tied to tangible assets like the US dollar. This law now allows banks to create and launch their own digital currencies.The Securities and Exchange Commission, led by Paul Atkins, whom Trump appointed, has also made creating rules for cryptocurrency a top priority. In comparison, this is a complete change from the Biden administration, which was hostile toward digital assets.Greggs explained.Until recently, the Big Four accounting firms had largely avoided auditing crypto businesses in the US. They also set strict conditions for working with crypto clients, partly because US regulators were wary of the sector. Regulators worldwide have long raised concerns about crypto, citing risks to consumers and financial stability, as well as its use in fraud and money laundering.After a shift in US policy, PwC began actively advising companies on how they could use crypto technology. According to Griggs, PwC has told clients that tools like stablecoins could help make payment systems more efficient.Other Big Four companies are moving in the same direction. Deloitte, which has audited Coinbase since 2020, released its first “digital assets roadmap” for crypto accounting in May. KPMG has said 2025 could be a turning point for wider digital asset adoption and is promoting services focused on crypto compliance and risk management.PwC has also added crypto-related audit clients, including Bitcoin miner Mara Holdings, which appointed PwC in March. The firm is also pitching tax advice linked to digital assets.Griggs became PwC’s US senior partner in 2024 after nearly 30 years at the firm, during which he led the audit of Goldman Sachs and worked on career development programmes.He said PwC had to bring in outside talent to strengthen its crypto expertise. This included hiring senior partners such as Cheryl Lesnik, who rejoined PwC after spending three years working with crypto clients at a smaller accounting firm.Griggs added.
Article Summary: PwC US CEO Paul Griggs said the company has decided to ‘lean in’ to cryptocurrency work. This follows the Trump administration’s support for digital assets such as Bitcoin. PwC has also added crypto-related audit clients, including Bitcoin miner Mara Holdings.

Article Title: Meta's AI research lab that "some insiders" said is 'dying a slow death' sees another top level exit as VP Jitendra Malik announces his resignation
Article Text:
Meta's AI research division, FAIR, is experiencing significant leadership departures, with VP Jitendra Malik joining Amazon's robotics team. This follows Chief AI Scientist Yann LeCun's exit, signaling a shift from fundamental research to commercial AI products. The unit faces internal turmoil and resource constraints as Meta prioritizes generative AI initiatives.

FAIR's identity crisis: From blue-sky research to product focus

Tensions simmer as LeCun criticizes LLM-focused strategy





Meta's famed AI research division has lost yet another senior leader, with VP Jitendra Malik announcing his departure to join Amazon's robotics efforts. The exit comes amid mounting turmoil at FAIR (Fundamental AI Research), which some former employees have described as "dying a slow death" as Meta pivots aggressively toward commercial AI products. Malik's resignation follows chief AI scientist Yann LeCun's recent departure and adds to a growing exodus of top researchers who helped build Meta's reputation as an AI powerhouse.Malik, who split his time between Meta's FAIR lab and UC Berkeley, announced on January 4 that he will lead Amazon's robotics research in San Francisco starting January 5. "It is time to move on," he wrote on X, highlighting accomplishments including video action recognition models, tactile sensors, and the recent SAM 3D breakthrough in computer vision.The departure caps a tumultuous year for FAIR, a unit once considered Meta's crown jewel in AI development. Since CEO Mark Zuckerberg launched his "year of intensity" push in January 2025, the lab has undergone multiple reorganizations, faced budget constraints, and seen more than half the authors of the original Llama research paper leave within months of publication.Former FAIR researchers told Fortune earlier this year that Meta has steadily deprioritized open-ended exploration in favor of product-driven initiatives under the GenAI organization.The lab now gets less computing power than teams focused on generative AI, according to ex-employees, though Meta declined to confirm resource allocation details.In August, Meta consolidated its AI efforts by dividing the Superintelligence Labs into four teams, creating confusion over project ownership and team assignments. The reshuffling was followed by 600 job cuts in October, and Chief AI Officer Alexandr Wang framed the layoffs necessary to accelerate decision-making.That instability was compounded when LeCun left to pursue his own project on "world models"—a path different from that of the large language models that now define Meta's approach to AI. In a December Financial Times interview, LeCun admitted Meta's Llama 4 results were "fudged a little bit" and criticized the company's "LLM-pilled" direction as incompatible with achieving superintelligence.Former research scientist Tian Yuandong, who left Meta in November, told Chinese media that internal conflicts emerged as computing resources became scarce amid the industrywide LLM race. Another ex-employee, Joena Zhang, wrote that "nobody really knew what anyone was doing" during the first half of 2025 at what's now called Meta Superintelligence Labs.Meta says it remains committed to FAIR, and employee sentiment surveys of recent times indicate improvement: Optimism was at 80% by late 2025.
Article Summary: Meta's AI research division, FAIR, is experiencing significant leadership departures. VP Jitendra Malik announced his departure to join Amazon's robotics efforts. This follows Chief AI Scientist Yann LeCun's exit, signaling a shift from fundamental research to commercial AI products.

Article Title: After the post goes viral, Google engineer says: The most-divisive subject for software engineers today is ...
Article Text:
AI generated image for representation

Coding Agents have divided developers across the spectrum



How good or bad is the quality of code AI can generate

Complimenting a competitor





A Google principal engineer named Jaaana Dogan has almost gone 'viral' along with her post on how AI has transformed coding in the last one year. In a post on X, formerly Twitter, Dogan wrote, "I'm not joking and this isn't funny. We have been trying to build distributed agent orchestrators at Google since last year. There are various options, not everyone is aligned... I gave Claude Code a description of the problem, it generated what we built last year in an hour." The post that has so far received almost 7 million views has triggered a debate on the role of AI tools like Claude, Google Gemini and others in software coding, with advocates on both sides.Soon after her post on using Claude Code for coding went viral, Dogan clarified that the code generated is not perfect but a good start. "It's not perfect and I'm iterating on it but this is where we are right now. If you are skeptical of coding agents, try it on a domain you are already an expert of. Build something complex from scratch where you can be the judge of the artifacts," she wrote. Talking of Vibe Coding, and how it existed in some form earlier too, she wrote, "The idea of everyone building software intimidates people.For me, growing up in the 80s and early 90s was unique because we used to program our own personal computers. Programming was an activity for everyone who had a computer."Dogan lamented that Coding Agents have divided the developer community and that she has never seen a trend that has been as divisive. "Since working on programming languages, I haven't seen this kind of polarized response from the developer community. There is a ton of hype & fluff about coding agents, which unfortunately often drowns out the genuinely good work being done. Things don't have to be this divisive." She added in another after a series of posts on the topic, "Coding agents are the most divisive subject. There are people who genuinely want to learn, there are skeptics, and there are people who are so dogmatic that they want to remove all sorts of communication on this subject. 2026 will be an interesting year."Dogan said that the developer community has always been divided in camps, and went on to describe three. She wrote: "The developer community has always been divided into a few camps:- People who are open to new modern tools- People who are building tools with new modern toolsand- People who think you should lose your job for using any modern tools."When prompted on the quality of the code generated by Claude, Dogan said, "To cut through the noise on this topic, it’s helpful to provide more more context:- We have built several versions of this system last year. - There are tradeoffs and there hasn't been a clear winner.- When prompted with the best ideas that survived, coding agents are able to go very far and generate a good decent toy version in an hour or so."The Google engineer called all the controversy around Coding Agents on layoffs. "All the controversy around coding agents is just a symptom. Where we are as an industry and the state of the job market is the main issue here since the beginning," she said.When asked about using a competitor's tool, Dogan said, "This industry has never been a zero-sum game, so it’s easy to give credit where it’s due even when it's a competitor. Claude Code is impressive work, I'm excited and more motivated to push us all forward."
Article Summary: Google engineer Jaaana Dogan has almost gone 'viral' along with her post on how AI has transformed coding in the last one year. The post that has so far received almost 7 million views has triggered a debate on the role of AI tools like Claude, Google Gemini and others in software coding.

Article Title: Ten technology trends to watch in 2026
Article Text:
After years of AI hype, 2026 brings a reality check. Companies need to prove their billion-dollar bets are worth it. Data centres are spreading globally, straining power grids. AI agents are moving from pilots to production. Robots are getting smarter. New hardware forms are arriving. Meanwhile, tech billionaires keep getting richer. The gap between hype and deployment is shrinking fast, and 2026 could turn out to be a real pivoting year.

AI shifts from hype to payback

Data centres spread across the globe

Work gets reimagined

Hardware gets weird new forms

Computing gets smarter, not just bigger

New models go beyond text

Robots become real(er)

The startup birth rate soars

Tech billionaires get even richer

What the 2026 really looks like





After years of AI hype and billion-dollar bets, 2026 is shaping up to be a reality check for the tech industry. Companies that dumped money into generative AI tools now face a simple question: show us the value, or shut it down.The pace of change isn't slowing. If anything, it's getting faster. Tools that seemed cutting-edge six months ago already feel outdated. Companies are racing to stay ahead, while also trying to prove their investments weren't wasted.Here are the ten trends in technology to watch out for in 2026.The experimental phase is over. Enterprises spent 2024 and 2025 testing AI pilots and proof-of-concept projects. Now they want measurable returns on those investments."2026 is the 'show me the money' year for AI," says Venky Ganesan, a partner at Menlo Ventures. Companies will demand hard ROI numbers. Those that can't deliver value will see their software renewals drop and their fundraising dry up.This pressure will split the market. Some AI companies will thrive by solving specific problems well. Others will struggle or fail entirely. Ganesan predicts at least one major AI company will face severe financial trouble or bankruptcy in 2026.The flip side: successful companies could go public. Both OpenAI and SpaceX are eyeing IPOs at valuations near $1 trillion. If these launches succeed, they'll create a wave of new wealth and validate AI's business potential.You heard a lot about data centres in 2025. Get ready to hear more in 2026.The infrastructure boom that started in the US and China is going global. India is attracting massive investment from tech giants. Microsoft committed $17.5 billion to new data centres there. Before Microsoft's CEO left the stage at that announcement, Amazon declared it would spend $35 billion on its own facilities. Google and Meta quickly followed with their own multi-billion dollar plans.Southeast Asia is seeing double-digit growth in data centre capacity. Brazil wants to become Latin America's hub. Saudi Arabia and the UAE struck $600 billion in AI deals with the US, including plans for the largest AI campus outside America.This expansion creates real problems. These facilities consume enormous amounts of electricity and water. In hot regions, cooling requirements push consumption even higher. Brazil has already seen blackouts tied to data centre demand. Local communities often can't find out how much power and water a facility will use, thanks to legal secrecy.China offers a warning: just because you build it doesn't mean they'll come. The country rushed to construct about 150 new data centres in 2024. Now up to 80% of that new computing capacity sits unused, struggling to find customers.AI hasn't replaced most workers yet. Even though it has impacted a big number of workers, changing how work gets done in particular niches.Coding looks completely different than it did five years ago. Developers use AI assistants that can generate, debug, and refactor code. The technology has matured enough that these tools genuinely save time. Customer service is being handed over to chatbots, despite customer frustration.AI agents were the buzzword of 2025, but most stayed in pilot programs. Only 11% of organisations actually deployed them in production, despite 38% running tests. The gap between pilot and production tells the real story. Many companies automated broken processes instead of redesigning their operations from scratch. That approach rarely works.In 2026, agents will become more capable and trustworthy. They'll handle complex, multi-step tasks without constant human oversight. Think booking entire trips, negotiating better service rates, or managing workflows across different systems. "A year from now, answering questions will be the least useful thing AI can do," says Fidji Simo, OpenAI's CEO of applications. "We'll have proactive AI assistants constantly running in the background, getting things done for us. "But there's a catch. Many companies will spin out hundreds of agents per employee, only to see most sit idle. Without proper integration into existing workflows, these agents become expensive shelfware. The winners will be companies that connect agents to deterministic systems and give them clear, focused tasks.The smartphone has looked basically the same for a decade: a big black screen with some buttons on the side. That's changing.Apple is rumoured to release a folding phone in 2026. Android devices have already gone this route, even including some phones that fold twice. But Apple's loyal customer base could make folding screens mainstream.Then, a lot of others are also racing to build the first successful AI hardware device. OpenAI invested $6.5 billion in Jony Ive's startup, which is working on a physical AI product. The Humane pin and Friend necklace both made noise but never caught on. Humane has already shut down.Smart glasses present the most promising direction. They're already popular, and Meta dominates the space. In 2026, expect these devices to get smarter and more common. They offer a natural way to interact with AI without pulling out your phone.You'll also see AI show up in places you didn't ask for it. Samsung already added its Bixby assistant to refrigerators back in 2024. Hotels might offer smart duvets. Your rental car might have an AI assistant. Not all of this will be useful or wanted.The AI infrastructure race is shifting from raw scale to efficiency. You can't keep throwing more computing power at every problem."2026 will be the year of frontier versus efficient model classes," says Kaoutar El Maghraoui, a principal research scientist at IBM. Next to huge models with billions of parameters, you'll see efficient, hardware-aware models running on modest accelerators.The hardware race won't only be about GPUs anymore. ASICs, chiplet designs, analogue inference, and quantum-assisted optimisers will all mature. A new class of chips designed specifically for running AI agents could emerge.Think of it like air traffic control for AI workloads. Computing power will be packed more densely and routed dynamically. If one job slows, another moves in instantly. Nothing sits idle. This makes infrastructure smarter, more sustainable, and more adaptable.Quantum computing is also reaching an inflection point. Microsoft, Google, and others believe quantum machines will start tackling problems that classical computers can't handle. Hybrid systems that combine quantum, AI, and supercomputers could drive breakthroughs in materials science, drug development, and climate modelling.Large language models dominated AI development for the past few years. They predict the next word in a sequence. In 2026, a different approach could take centre stage: world models.World models work by learning from videos, simulations, and spatial inputs. Instead of predicting the next word, they predict what happens next in the physical world. They model how things move over time.This matters for robotics, video games, and any application where AI needs to understand cause and effect without being explicitly programmed. World models can grasp concepts like gravity or momentum just by watching.Google, Meta, and Chinese companies like Tencent are all developing world models. Yann LeCun, one of AI's pioneers, left Meta to launch a world model startup. Fei-Fei Li's company World Labs released its first model in 2025.At the same time, Europe is moving in a different direction: small language models. These are lightweight versions of LLMs designed to run on smartphones or low-powered computers. They use fewer parameters and consume less energy, but they can still handle text generation, translation, and question-answering.Small models make economic sense amid talk of the AI bubble bursting. They cost less to build, less to run, and don't require massive data centres. European governments are increasingly wary of depending on American AI infrastructure, which could accelerate investment in smaller, more sustainable models.AI security becomes mission-criticalAI creates a cybersecurity paradox: the same capabilities driving business innovation are also introducing new risks. In 2026, organisations will face mounting pressure to secure AI systems while defending against AI-powered attacks.The threats are multiplying fast. Shadow AI deployments bypass security controls. Adversarial attacks manipulate models into producing wrong outputs. AI agents operating with broad system access create new attack surfaces. "Every agent should have similar security protections as humans," says Vasu Jakkal, corporate vice president of Microsoft Security.Even OpenAI is sounding the alarm. CEO Sam Altman recently acknowledged that AI models are "starting to present some real challenges," including models that are "so good at computer security they are beginning to find critical vulnerabilities." The company is actively hiring a new Head of Preparedness to study emerging AI-related risks, from cybersecurity threats to mental health impacts. The role comes with a $555,000 salary, reflecting how seriously the company takes these challenges.Companies will need to secure four domains: data, models, applications, and infrastructure. Defenders are fighting back with AI agents for red teaming, adversarial training, and automated threat detection at machine speed.Robots are nothing like what they used to be. From pre-programmed machines, they are evolving into adaptive systems capable of perception, learning, and autonomous operation. Physical AI is breaking out of warehouses and into mainstream use.Amazon has already deployed its millionth robot, and if the company is to be believed, AI coordinates entire fleets, and that’s helping them save travel time by about 10%. At BMW plants, cars now drive themselves along production routes. The real magic, however, is when world models combine with robotics, allowing systems to comprehend their surroundings and adapt to surprises.The next frontier is humanoid robots that can navigate spaces designed for humans, as companies race to craft machines capable of doing just that. The potential stretches across manufacturing, healthcare, and disaster response, and is increasingly accessible beyond the early adopters as costs fall.AI coding tools are making it easier than ever to build software. The result: a wave of new startups hitting the market in 2026.Tools like Replit, Cursor, and Loveable let people build products without engineering backgrounds. You can go from idea to working software faster than ever before. Building AI agents is also getting simpler. Business users can create them without touching code.Not every startup will make it. Markets will get crowded. Competition will heat up. But the sheer number of new companies will reshape the landscape and push established players to move faster.Tech's wealthiest executives are about to get a lot wealthier. Ten top earners added $550 billion to their fortunes in 2025. The trend isn't slowing down.Two massive IPOs are coming: OpenAI and SpaceX, both valued near $1 trillion. SpaceX's debut will add tens of billions to Elon Musk's net worth, which already sits around $600 billion. He's also eligible for two Tesla pay packages worth a combined $1.056 trillion. Sam Altman stands to benefit from OpenAI's listing, along with major backers like Microsoft. Jeff Bezos Mark Zuckerberg , and Satya Nadella have all seen their wealth climb as AI investments pay off.Larry Ellison might be the exception. Oracle's stock dropped hard as investors questioned AI spending, erasing $80 billion in market value.Every trend in tech seems to point in one direction: more wealth flowing upward. The AI boom, the data centre buildout, the chip shortage, the agent revolution—all of it concentrates power and money in fewer hands. A handful of tech executives now wield enormous influence over technology that affects everyone's daily life.Every trend here points to the same reality: the distance between hype and deployment is collapsing. Tech used to take years to move from labs to living rooms. Now it takes months, sometimes weeks.This creates winners and losers fast. Companies that can't prove AI's value will fold. Workers in certain fields will find their jobs radically different or gone entirely. Cities welcoming data centres might face power shortages they didn't plan for. Meanwhile, a small group of tech billionaires keeps getting richer off all of it, concentrating more control over systems that affect billions of people.The pace isn't slowing down. If anything, 2026 will be the year when that becomes impossible to ignore.
Article Summary: After years of AI hype, 2026 brings a reality check. Companies need to prove their billion-dollar bets are worth it. Data centres are spreading globally, straining power grids. AI agents are moving from pilots to production. Robots are getting smarter. New hardware forms are arriving.

Article Title: Samsung Electronics co-CEO shares 'Google plan' to increase Galaxy smartphone sale
Article Text:
No company immune to memory chip shortage





Samsung Electronics co-CEO T M Roh said that the company aims to double the number of its mobile devices with AI features powered by Google's Gemini in 2026. By 2025, the South Korean firm had rolled out Gemini-backed AI features to about 400 million mobile products, including smartphones and tablets. It now plans to boost that figure to 800 million in the current year. “We will apply AI to all products, all functions, and all services as quickly as possible,” Roh told news agency Reuters in his first interview since becoming the company’s co-CEO in November. With the move, Samsung seeks to reclaim its lost crown from Apple in the smartphone market, the report says. It also aims to fend off competition from Chinese rivals not only in mobile telephones, but televisions and home appliances, all overseen by Roh.Roh said that other than search, consumers o frequently use a range of generative AI editing and productivity tools for images and others, as well as translation and summary features on smartphones.As per the report, Roh expects the adoption of AI to accelerate, as Samsung's surveys on awareness of its Galaxy AI brand jumped to a level of 80% from about 30% in just one year. "Even though the AI technology might seem a bit doubtful right now, within six months to a year, these technologies will become more widespread," he said.According to the report, a global shortage of memory chips is a boon to Samsung's mainstay semiconductor business, but it may impact margins on the smartphone business, its second largest revenue source."As this situation is unprecedented, no company is immune to its impact," Roh told the agency, adding that the crisis affects not only mobile phones but other consumer electronics, from TVs to home appliances.He did not rule out raising product prices, saying some impact was "inevitable" from a surge in memory chip prices, but Samsung, the world’s No.1 TV maker, is working with partners on longer term strategies to minimise the impact.During the interaction, Roh acknowledged that the market for foldable phones has been growing slower than expected. He attributed this to the engineering complexities and lack of applications suitable for the hardware design, but expected the segment to go mainstream in the next two or three years. He said that a "very high" rate of foldable phone users opt for the same segment for their next purchase.
Article Summary: Samsung aims to double the number of its mobile devices with AI features by 2026. By 2025, the South Korean firm had rolled out Gemini-backed AI features to about 400 million mobile products, including smartphones and tablets. With the move, Samsung seeks to reclaim its lost crown from Apple in the smartphone market.

Article Title: Elon Musk announces Neuralink breakthrough, calling it 'big deal'; says: I am confident that ...
Article Text:
Elon Musk thanks FDA for Blindsight





Elon Musk has announced a major Neuralink Breakthrough. The Billionaire said that his brain-computer interface company Neuralink can possibly restore full body functionality. Elon Musk's brain implant company Neuralink will start "high-volume production" of brain-computer interface devices and move to an entirely automated surgical procedure in 2026, Musk said in a post on the social media platform X on Wednesday. “I am confident at this point that restoring full body functionality is possible with Neuralink,” the Tesla and SpaceX founder said in a post on the social media platform X, formerly Twitter. “Neuralink can essentially help bridge communications from the cortex, past the point in the neck or spine, where the nerves are damaged. It is possible from a physics standpoint to physically restore full body functionality,” he said in a video post.The breakthrough focuses on the motor cortex, restoring “full body functionality” for people with severed spinal cords. The motor cortex technology feature was first announced by Elon Musk in 2022, and the testing began in humans in the same year.According to Musk, any device that can be controlled via computer or phone can be controlled by a Neuralink implant.The device includes a chip that replaces a small piece of bone and is connected to the brain via a series of thin, threaded electrodes. The company's N1 implant includes 1,024 electrodes distributed among 64 threads, according to the company's website. “Neuralink will start high-volume production of brain-computer interface devices and move to a streamlined, almost entirely automated surgical procedure in 2026. Device threads will go through the dura without the need to remove it. This is a big deal,” he shared on X.Neuralink eyes mass brain implant production in 2026In September 2025, Neuralink announced that it had implanted its device in 12 patients. The year 2025 also saw Neuralink raising $650 million in Series E funding, led by investors including ARK Invest, Sequoia Capital, and Founders Fund, valuing the company at approximately $9 billion.On January 1 this year, Musk's California-based neurotechnology company announced taking major steps toward restoring vision, with a brain implant that allows the visually impaired, even those blind from birth.Blindsight, Neuralink’s brain chip aimed at restoring vision, received “breakthrough device” designation from the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in September 2024. The company is expected to begin high-volume production of the device this year.Elon Musk said that Blindsight will help people who have lost both eyes, and they will be able to see. He also claimed that, provided the visual cortex remains intact, the device can restore vision even in people who have been blind since birth. "Blindsight will enable those who have total loss of vision, including if they've lost their eyes or the optic nerve, or maybe have never seen, or even blind from birth, to be able to see again," said Musk. Thanking US-FDA, Musk wrote, "To set expectations correctly, the vision will be at first be low resolution, like Atari graphics, but eventually it has the potential be better than natural vision and enable you to see in infrared, ultraviolet or even radar wavelengths, like Geordi La Forge. Much appreciated, @US_FDA."
Article Summary: Elon Musk's brain implant company Neuralink will start "high-volume production" of brain-computer interface devices and move to an entirely automated surgical procedure in 2026. The breakthrough focuses on the motor cortex, restoring “full body functionality” for people with severed spinal cords. “Neuralink can essentially help bridge communications from the cortex, past the point in the neck or spine, where the nerves are damaged,” he said.

Article Title: CES 2026: Samsung puts OLED screens on cassettes and turntables that have AI in them
Article Text:
Samsung Display is turning heads at CES 2026 with retro-inspired AI OLED Cassette and Turntable concepts. These devices blend vintage audio aesthetics with modern OLED screens, showcasing the technology's versatility. The cassette features a 1.5-inch round display, while the turntable boasts a larger 13.4-inch circular screen, offering interactive music experiences and visual moods directly on the units.

Samsung's retro concepts are part of a bigger OLED showcase





Samsung Display has cooked up something nostalgic for CES 2026. The company is showing off two retro-inspired concept devices—the AI OLED Cassette and AI OLED Turntable—that take vintage audio design and give it a modern twist with OLED screens. It's part of Samsung's effort to show that its display technology can work in pretty much any gadget you can think of, even ones that look like they belong in the '80s.The AI OLED Cassette features a compact 1.5-inch round OLED display, styled to look like a classic audio cassette. Images show it sporting a smartwatch-style interactive screen alongside what appears to be a status display. Meanwhile, the AI OLED Turntable steps things up with a much larger 13.4-inch circular OLED that seems to be touch-controlled, though Samsung hasn't revealed exactly what you'd use such a big round screen for on a turntable-inspired device.Both devices fall under Samsung's "AI Edge Vision Station" at CES, where the company is showing off various speaker-type AI assistants with displays. The idea is that instead of relying on external smart devices like traditional Bluetooth speakers, these concepts let you see music recommendations, pick songs, and even set visual moods right on the device itself.Samsung is positioning these as proof that OLED's flexibility—it can be curved, spherical, or circular—opens up creative possibilities that LCD simply can't match.While it's unclear if either product will actually hit shelves, they're certainly conversation starters.The company is also unveiling more practical innovations at CES, including ultra-thin laptop displays, 4,500-nit QD-OLED TVs, and automotive screens. But the cassette and turntable? Those are pure fun, showing Samsung isn't afraid to experiment with form factors that challenge conventional thinking about what a display should look like.
Article Summary: Samsung's AI OLED Cassette and Turntable show off the technology's versatility. The cassette features a 1.5-inch round display, while the turntable boasts a larger 13.4-inch circular screen. Both devices fall under Samsung's "AI Edge Vision Station" at CES 2026.

Article Title: Palo Alto Networks' top exec calls AI Agents 2026's biggest insider threat that an 'impressed' Salesforce CEO said may rename the company after
Article Text:
When Chinese spies 'told' Claude to break into about 30 companies





AI agents are seen as one of the biggest productivity tools by technology companies. From Microsoft to Amazon and more, all technology companies are talking about the potential of AI agents. Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff went to the extent of saying that he might rename the company 'Agentforce'. In December last year, a Salesforce employee told Business Insider that the company might change its official corporate name to Agentforce. Later in an interview, Salesforce CEO Benioff confirmed this is a possibility. "It might," Benioff said and added, "That would not shock me." Salesforce CEO said that now customers don't want to hear about the cloud anymore and that he learned during recent focus groups ahead of the company's annual Dreamforce conference in October. Instead, clients want to talk about AI agents."I dropped the word cloud totally," he said. "I did it at Dreamforce. Did you notice I never used it in the keynote? We learned in focus groups customers don't talk about cloud anymore. They just want to talk about their agentic interface." However, Palo Alto Networks Chief Security Intel Officer Wendi Whitmore does not seem to agree with Benioff. In an interview to The Register, Whitmore said that AI agents represent the new insider threat to companies in 2026."The CISO and security teams find themselves under a lot of pressure to deploy new technology as quickly as possible, and that creates this massive amount of pressure - and massive workload - that the teams are under to quickly go through procurement processes, security checks, and understand if the new AI applications are secure enough for the use cases that these organizations have," Whitmore told The Register. "And that's created this concept of the AI agent itself becoming the new insider threat," she added."When we look through the defender lens, a lot of what the agentic capabilities allow us to do is start thinking more strategically about how we defend our networks, versus always being caught in this reactive situation," Whitmore said.Whitmore, along with just about every other cyber execs that The Register spoke to for the report, pointed to the "Anthropic attack" in October 2025 as an example. Chinese cyber spies used Anthropic's Claude Code AI tool to attempt digital break-ins at about 30 high-profile companies and government organizations – and the government-backed snoops "succeeded in a small number of cases," according to a report from the AI company. The mid-September operation targeted large tech companies, financial institutions, chemical manufacturers, and government agencies.While Whitmore doesn't anticipate AI agents to carry out any fully autonomous attacks this year, she does expect AI to be a force multiplier for network intruders. "You're going to see these really small teams almost have the capability of big armies," she said. "They can now leverage AI capabilities to do so much more of the work that previously they would have had to have a much larger team to execute against."
Article Summary: Palo Alto Networks Chief Security Intel Officer Wendi Whitmore said that AI agents represent the new insider threat to companies in 2026. Whitmore, along with just about every other cyber execs that The Register spoke to for the report, pointed to the "Anthropic attack" in October 2025. Chinese cyber spies used Anthropic's Claude Code AI tool to attempt digital break-ins at about 30 high-profile companies.
